description.narrative: The ERRC's mission is to combat anti-gypsyism by; - exposing human rights abuse against all Roma, particularly Romani women, - litigating that abuse in court, and - mobilising Romani women and men; *to contest illegal practises, unjust power relations, environmental harm, and inequitable resource allocation, and *to contribute to positive sustainable development.

Romer i Europa är i många fall offer för diskriminering och deras mänskliga rättigheter respekteras inte. Kränkningar mot romers mänskliga rättigheter tar sig ofta uttryck i form av hatbrott som ej bestraffas; att romer får sämre möjligheter till utbildning; att romer har sämre tillgång till boende; samt att romer diskrimineras av olika myndligheter och rättsvårdande instanser. European Roma Rights Centre (ERRC) arbetar mot kränkningar mot Romer genom att i) driva rättsfall i nationella domstolar liksom i Europadomstolen; ii) bedriva evidens-baserat påverkansarbete, ofta kopplat till de rättsfall som bedrivs, för att få tillstånd policyförändringar och uppmärksamma makthavare på den bristande tillämpningen av existerande lagar; iii) bedriva forskning för att kunna sprida information om diskriminering och för att kunna påverka makthavare; iv) bedriva kapacitetsutveckling av romska enskilda organisationer så att de blir medvetna om sina rättigheter och förmögna att försvara dem. ERRC har verksamhet i hela Europa, men Sida stödjer deras verksamhet i ODA-länder. Föreliggande program omfattar verksamhet i AL, BiH, KS, ME, MD, MK, RS, TR och UA.

The Roma community in Europe (by 'Roma' is meant all Roma, with or without intersecting identities, and people who do not identify themselves as Roma, but are still targets of anti-gypsyism, such as those identifying as Travellers, Sinti, Ashkali or Egyptian) is daily exposed to discrimination, harrassement and abuse for the mere fact that they are Roma. Those degradations are influenced and often worsened by other inequalities associated with gender, gender identity, disability, age, sexual orientation, socio-economic status, language, residence status, nationality and many other characteristics.
Roma face rights violations such as forced evictions, police brutality, and lack of access to safe drinking water, sanitation, and other basic services and facilities. Societies primed for prejudice often interpret these rights violations as appropriate and natural.
The cooperation partner European Roma Rights Centre (ERRC) is targeting anti-gypsyism by • exposing human rights abuse against all Roma (particularly Romani women), • litigating that abuse in court, and • mobilising Romani women and men to contest illegal practices, unjust power relations, environmental harm, and inequitable resource allocation, and to contribute to positive sustainable development.
The tools ERRC uses include; i) mobilisation - mobilising and empowering Roma and the Roma movement to use the legal system and justice mechanism to claim their rights, ii) research-based advocacy and communication targeting those responsible for securing the rights of Roma, iii) strategic litigation (public interest and testing litigation as well as representing individual litigants in Strasbourg or Geneva), iv) information and communication about ERRC work and achievemts in various media.
Anti-gypsyism is present throughout Europe (defined as CoE 47 member states). However, Sida can only target ODA-countries why the focus of Sida funds via ERRC are the Western Balkans, Turkey and Eastern Partnership countries. The ERRC program proposal includes AL, BiH, KS, MD, ME, MK, RS, TR and UA.

description.narrative:
Among the results are:
- In 2018, ERCC focused on the statelessness issue with the #RomaBelong project, with the aim of eliminating Romani statelessness in Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, Montenegro, Macedonia, Serbia, and Ukraine, and of ensuring protection for those Romani people who are stateless. In 2019, North Macedonias Parliament introduced a law to ratify the Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness, in part attributed to the RomaBelong project.
- On 23 October 2018, the European Union introduced the new Drinking Water Directive, which, for the first time in the history of EU water policy, recognises the challenges in access to water for vulnerable groups and makes direct references to Roma.
- In early 2019, the ERRC published a report on the reproductive rights of Romani women in Ukraine. Research conducted by the ERRC and the Romani womens organisation, Roma Fund Chiricli, found that pregnant Romani women face segregation and other forms of degrading, discriminatory treatment when accessing reproductive healthcare, and especially when giving birth.. Following the publication of the report, the ERRC and Chiricli turned to the Ombudsmans office to apply pressure on the authorities to cease abusive and discriminatory practices. The Ombudsman responded positively, and began working with our local partner to launch a training and inspection programme in late 2019.
- A verdict in North Macedonia in 2021 when the court in Skopje ruled that the Ministry of Health discriminated against Romani minors with drug addiction problems by not providing them with treatment or rehabilitation. The Ministry has been ordered to adopt a specific treatment programme for child drug users.
- A ruling in 2018 for the Albanian authorities to supply clean water for Roma after discrimination. Macedonian Court Rules Against Swimming Pool for Discriminating Against Roma from 2018. A public pool in Bitola barred Roma from entering during very hot days when it was particularly busy.
